none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, August 20, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, August 20, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 12 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,

DEPARTMENT OF
CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS.
H. H. DINWIDDIE.

College Station, Texas, Aug. 20 1882

My dear McInnis -
As you are now on your travels among
the Thousand Islands and other strange lands this letter
may not reach you, but I will write it anyhow upon
the chance. Your letter describing your impressions of
the village of New York and its surrounding hamlets was
brimfull of interest. I anticipate many pleasant talks on
the subject of your adventures in those out of the way places
when you return to this land of "cities". Meantime we
have been jogging on without one excitement except the
organization of the University. As you naturally take
an interest in that I must give you some home com=
ments on it, you having I doubt not already received
the main facts through the newspapers. The way in
which the regents have fired over the heads of us small
fry is amusing to me. I am actually laughing as I write
about it. It reminds me of the circus clown who temptingly
held an orange under the nose of a small boy down
by the ring and then deliberately pitched it at a grave
citizen on the top bench. To think of the Texas teachers
of high and low degree all crowding into Austin with
Hogg in the van expecting every moment to be called
in and congratulated, to imagine the dry grin with

[Header]

2
[1883, Aug. 20]
Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,

DEPARTMENT OF
CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS.
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
College Station, Texas, ........................ 188...

[Body]

which they saw the two oranges go flying up to Michigan
and New England aimed at Judge Cooley and Mr.
Harris! How truly thankful I am that I let my
good genius whisper effectively to me not to be in Aus=
tin at that time! What a providential escape from being
one of the grinners - for although I suppose my name
is before the board I can congratulate myself that
I have done nothing to compromise myself in the least;
I have not even made a strictly formal application.
I had a long letter from Col. James yesterday - he was
there, though of course not an applicant himself.
He seems somewhat disgusted - says the regents think
they must import the brains for their university "a la
Hollingsworth". The best thing now will be to watch
Hogg simmer down. He has been charging around
Texas lecturing on the "Head, Heart & Hand" all the
summer, getting himself notorious by startling statis=
tics and astonishing prophecies &c. at last he winds
up at Austin and stands with open mouth to see his
dainty tidbits tossed to - Michigan & New Hampshire!
You have seen that the salaries offered Judge Cooley and
Mr. Harris respectively are $3000 and $4000. The im=
pression is that they will hardly draw those big fish.

[Header]

3.
[1882, Aug. 20]

Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,

DEPARTMENT OF
CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS.
H. H. DINWIDDIE.

College Station, Texas, .................... 188...

[Body]

However the point is that they show the "animus" of the regents and pretty well wet-blanket the native aspirants. I dont know that I am sorry much for any body except Bringhurst. To be sure the majority of places are yet to be filled, but the supposition is that the next call will include Sylvester, Gildersleeve, Whitney, Roscoe, Tyndall and Chandler. It is to be an University – "you bet!" Pardon slang. I am sure you will acquit me of soreness in writing thus. It is really very funny to me; to think of all the great expectations, and the cool ignoring of the same! You and I will I hope be colleagues in the A & M. C. yet for some time.

Prof. Georgeson has gone to Sherman – scared by the yellow fever. Col. Cole has taken his family to the same place. Gartner & I "hold the fort".

Mrs. D. Rob. & I will probably go to Lampasas next week, remain there till the middle of Sept. then go to Austin where I hope to see you and take several glasses of Budweiser with you.

You have of course heard of the death of Estill. It was sad news to us all. I hope this letter will reach you. With kindest regards from Mrs. Dinwiddie

[Signature]

Yours faithfully –
H. H. Dinwiddie
